Of these, only Einstein field equations have been spiced up with decorative indices (which actually hide a system of ten nonlinear partial differential equations). Euler's identity is massaged to include both 0 and 1 (since including both the additive and multiplicative identities is "more profound") since the interpretation of ''eiÏ€'' = ''-1'' is otherwise not necessarily intuitive; using the ratio of a circle's circumference to its ''radius'' (ğœ) rather than its diameter results in ''eiğœ = 1'' which can be interpreted as a statement that "one trip around the circle leaves you back where you started". In the title text, Randall mentions the {{w|Drag equation}}, which is attributed to {{w|Lord Rayleigh}}. In {{w|fluid dynamics}}, the drag equation is a formula used to calculate the force of drag experienced by an object due to movement through a fully enclosing fluid. The equation is ''F''d = Â½''Ïu''2''c''d''A''. Here ''F''d is the drag force, Ï the mass density of the fluid, u the relative flow velocity, ''c''d the {{w|drag coefficient}} and A is the area. Randall jokes that the factor of Â½ in the equation is meaningless and purely decorative, since the drag coefficients, ''c''d, are already unitless and could just as easily be half as big thus leaving out the Â½ in front of the equation. The Â½ is thus just an example of a "decorative constant." The usual reason for including the factor of Â½ is that it is part of the formula for kinetic energy that appears in the derivation of the drag equation, i.e. Â½''Ïu''2. However, modern treatments are so condensed that this factor of Â½ is often smuggled in with no explanation. Since we can choose the constants to be whatever we want, it could be possible to absorb the Â½ into the drag coefficient ''c''d, but that does not mean it is unmotivated, since it comes from the kinetic energy. Still, Randall quotes Frank White's ''[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Fluid-Mechanics-Frank-White/dp/007119911X Fluid Mechanics''] textbook, [https://books.google.com/books?id=wGweAQAAIAAJ&q=traditional%20tribute&redir_esc=y which two times] calls it "a traditional tribute to Euler and Bernoulli." According to White, the factor of Â½ rather comes from the calculation of the projected area of the object being dragged. Randall has brought up this point before, in his book, "[[How To]]". The line from White probably refers to renowned mathematicians {{w|Leonhard Euler}} and {{w|Daniel Bernoulli}}. Euler who is held to be one of the greatest mathematicians in history worked directly with Daniel and was a friend of the {{w|Bernoulli family}}, that produced eight mathematically gifted academics. Bernoulli is known for modifying the definition of ''vis viva'' (what we now call kinetic energy) from ''mv''2 to Â½''mv''2, as motivated by the derivation from the impulse equation. In 1741, he wrote :[Define ''vis viva''] esse Â½ ''mvv'' = âˆ«''pdx''. That is, "define ''vis viva'' to be Â½ ''mv''2 = âˆ«''p''d''x''," where ''p'' is the force (from ''pressione'') and d''x'' is the differential of position (infinitesimal displacement). Today, this equation says that the kinetic energy imparted to an object at rest equals the work done on it. In the drag equation Â½ Ïu2 represents the dynamic pressure due to the kinetic energy of the fluid, and hence the 1/2 makes sense to keep in the equation, and could thus easily be argued not to represent a decorative constant.
